headline.main: U.S. to Help Defray Russia's Expenses for the Space Station

results.snippet: The United States will help cash-strapped Russia keep its commitments to the  planned international space station by adding three space shuttle missions, one  to deliver a key Russian component to the station and two to ferry supplies to the existing...
results.lead_paragraph: The United States will help cash-strapped Russia keep its commitments to the planned international space station by adding three space shuttle missions, one to deliver a key Russian component to the station and two to ferry supplies to the existing Mir outpost, NASA officials said today. The officials said United States and Russian negotiators had rejected several Russian proposals designed to reduce its costs of assembling the international station, known as Alpha. But they said the United States had agreed to use shuttles to ferry the supplies to Mir and to place in orbit a Russian science module for Alpha to save Russia the expense of several rocket flights.

headline.main: Russell Colley, Designer Of Spacesuits, Is Dead at 97

results.snippet: Russell Colley, a thwarted women's fashion designer who used his consolation  career as a mechanical engineer to become the Calvin Klein of space wear, died on Sunday at the Ohio Masonic Home in Springfield, Ohio. He was 97.         By the time the...
results.lead_paragraph: Russell Colley, a thwarted women's fashion designer who used his consolation career as a mechanical engineer to become the Calvin Klein of space wear, died on Sunday at the Ohio Masonic Home in Springfield, Ohio. He was 97. By the time the United States began its efforts at manned space flight in the 1950's, Mr. Colley, a longtime engineer with the B. F. Goodrich Company in Akron, Ohio, was an old hand at outfitting high-altitude aviators.

headline.main: The Shuttle Takes Off for a High-Wire Act

results.snippet: The space shuttle Columbia roared aloft today on a difficult mission to tow miles of electrical cable through the hostile environment of outer space, its seven astronauts intent on advancing a futuristic way of studying Earth's atmosphere and of...
results.lead_paragraph: The space shuttle Columbia roared aloft today on a difficult mission to tow miles of electrical cable through the hostile environment of outer space, its seven astronauts intent on advancing a futuristic way of studying Earth's atmosphere and of powering and propelling spacecraft. Late Saturday, four Americans, two Italians and one Swiss astronaut on board the Columbia are to unreel a cable out to maximum length of 12.5 miles, making it the longest man-made object ever put in orbit. A similar test in 1992 failed after a safety bolt accidentally limited the unreeling of the cable to little more than 800 feet.

headline.main: The View From: West Hartford;Peering Into Space With a Little Help From NASA

results.snippet: THE Science Center of Connecticut, once known as the Children's Museum in West Hartford, is trying to re-establish itself as a fun-loving educational place for children and adults alike, but its long-term future remains uncertain.         Last...
results.lead_paragraph: THE Science Center of Connecticut, once known as the Children's Museum in West Hartford, is trying to re-establish itself as a fun-loving educational place for children and adults alike, but its long-term future remains uncertain. Last spring, the center hired a new operations director, Edward J. Forand Jr., a former Connecticut Deputy Treasurer and Deputy Comptroller, whose goal is to draw renewed attention to the West Hartford center. At the same time, center officials are studying whether to go ahead with a new state-of-the-art science center elsewhere.

headline.main: Satellite and Plans Are Adrift As a Stringlike Tether Snaps

results.snippet: Speeding around Earth at nearly five miles a second and working by remote control late yesterday, seven astronauts of the space shuttle Columbia were slowly unreeling from the shuttle's payload bay a long cable topped by a half-ton satellite when the...
results.lead_paragraph: Speeding around Earth at nearly five miles a second and working by remote control late yesterday, seven astronauts of the space shuttle Columbia were slowly unreeling from the shuttle's payload bay a long cable topped by a half-ton satellite when the tether, about 12 miles out and nearing its maximum extension of nearly 13 miles, suddenly and mysteriously broke in two. The tether and satellite flew away from the shuttle at a speed of about a hundred miles an hour, prematurely ending the nearly $450 million experiment.

headline.main: A Decade of Work Lost With Tether

results.snippet: Like a child watching a helium balloon slip from an outstretched hand, scientists looked on in distress as a half-ton satellite being towed by the space shuttle Columbia broke loose and floated into the black void, dangling 12  miles of frayed,...
results.lead_paragraph: Like a child watching a helium balloon slip from an outstretched hand, scientists looked on in distress as a half-ton satellite being towed by the space shuttle Columbia broke loose and floated into the black void, dangling 12 miles of frayed, curled cord. For those who had devoted years -- some of them, up to a decade -- to the electricity-generating project, it was a cruel blow, all the more so because everything had been going well until the accident.
